description.en: The course covers main issues in the philosophy of language, introducing the theories of meaning, semantics, and communication.
description.et: Aine käsitleb keelefilosoofia põhiteemasid, andes sissejuhatuse tähendusteooriasse, semantikasse ja kommunikatsiooniteooriasse.

objectives.en: The main general objective is to familiarize students with an important branch of the contemporary analytical philosophical tradition. The course will give an overview of the main concepts, topics and arguments in philosophy of language, develop the skill of reading philosophy texts and the philosophical writing skills.
objectives.et: Aine üldeesmärk on tutvustada filosoofiaüliõpilastele olulist osa tänapäeva analüütilisest filosoofiatraditsioonist. Kursus annab ülevaate keelefilosoofia põhimõistetest, probleemidest ja argumentidest, arendab filosoofiliste tekstide lugemisoskust ning filosoofilise kirjutamise oskust.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon successful completion of the course the students should:
1) master the most important concepts in philosophy of language,
2) know the main theories in philosophy of language and  understand their weaknesses and strengths,
learning_outcomes.et: 2) tunneb keelefilosoofia tähtsamaid teooriaid ja mõistab nende tugevusi ja nõrkusi,

learning_outcomes.en: 3) be able to read, understand and discuss texts on philosophy of language,
learning_outcomes.et: 3) suudab iseseisvalt lugeda tekste keelefilosoofiast ja neid kommenteerida,

learning_outcomes.en: 4) be competent in philosophical problem-setting and able to find relevant literature,
learning_outcomes.et: 4) oskab püstitada ja sõnastada filosoofilisi küsimusi ja otsida nende lahendamiseks relevantset kirjandust,

learning_outcomes.en: 5) know and apply the basics of philosophical essay writing.
learning_outcomes.et: 5) teab ja oskab rakendada filosoofilise essee kirjutamise põhialuseid.

independent_work.et:
We can divide independent work into two categories: formative and summative.

Formative independent work is not graded: its purpose is to help you learn the material of the course and to help you prepare for the activities we'll do in the seminars. This work will consist of active reading, note-taking, consumption of media, and preparatory writing tasks for seminars. These tasks will be specified by the course start date. To help students do this preparatory work efficiently, there will be a workshop early in the course on the use of generative AI for what we can call "discursive reading," where you upload a text to a generative AI interface, and converse with the interface, like you would converse with a tutor. The workshop will teach students how to use generative AI effectively for this purpose. The ability to do discursive reading should make it possible for students to do formative independent work more efficiently.

Summative independent work is graded: if you look at the assessment methods, you'll see that some assessments are done in the seminar itself, some are done at home, and some include both seminar and homework. The following summative (graded) tasks are partly done in seminars and partly at home (additional summative tasks are done in seminars only - see Assessment Methods for a full account):
3 * short argumentative essay (argument for the context-sensitivity of a novel expression; a speech act analysis; an assessment of how philosophy of language uses data (NB: this last task is based on a diary students keep throughout the course on the use of data in philosophy of language))
1 * Role-play/Social media sketch development (group work)
1* Development and recording of a scene that illustrates concepts from the course (group work)
NB: There is further summative graded work, but it's done in class (see Assessment Methods).

description.et: (15%) Attendance (you lose 2% for each absence unless a very good excuse is given -- you're allowed 2 good excuses).
(10%) Assessment: Fill out short quantitative and qualitative feedback form at the end of the course. Not graded - be honest, you get the points for completion.
(15%) Assessment (2 parts (7%, 8%)) - one from earlier part of course on formal semantics, one from later part on gradable adjectives).
(15%) Assessment: short argumentative paper - construction of own arguments for the context-sensitivity of expressions not already covered in the course.

(10%) Assessment: this task runs throughout the course - since the intuition and experiment stuff runs throughout the course. You will keep a diary about this for each week, and at some point you write up what they've seen. You have to offer an assessment of the extent to which philosophy of language is grounded in data. Short argumentative paper.
(10%) Assessment: Animated social media exchange between cognitive and generative linguists--you compose a dialogue between protagonists of this debate. (group work)

(10%) Assessment: teams act out and record scenes in which different kinds of content (presupposition, implicature) are communicated and their relation to deniability and resistance  made clear (example of this for implicature: great personality/attractive scene from When Harry Met Sally). (group work)

(15%) Assessment: you provide an analysis of a speech act (not already provided in class, but one from a list). You have to exchange each others' papers in class, provide feedback on them, and then rewrite them before submitting them. You also have to explore why an understanding of this speech act would be of interest to people with no interest in language for its own sake. Short argumentative paper.

grade_preconditions.et:
To receive a positive final grade, it is not required to complete all assessments.
If at least 44% of the possible 100% has been collected for the evaluated components, the student can get a positive grade. See the grading scale in the next section. But please be aware of the fact that several graded tasks are team-based. Don't put yourself into a position where you're going to let other people down.

grade_evaluation.et:
Assessments (7 altogether) -- 10+15+15+10+10+10+15=85%
Attendance -- 15%

Grades are based on student performance across all graded assignments. These are spread out throughout the course. The percentages below are for the sum of student performance across all graded assignments.

A 84%-100%
B 74%-83% 
C 64%-73% 
D 54%-63% 
E 44%-53%
F 0-33%

debt_elimination.et: No retakes. No overdue assignments are permitted UNLESS a good explanation is given in advance. Overdue assignments increase the logistical complexity of the course and, hence, the workload of lecturers.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.mandatory_materials: Full materials for the course will be provided in Moodle.
resources.recommended_materials:
Full materials for the course will be provided in Moodle. But if you want to get a sense of the ideas and approaches the course engages with, look at these.

Cognitive and Generative Linguistics
-	Lakoff, George, Women, Fire and Dangerous Things: What Categories Reveal About the Mind, University of Chicago Press, 1991. (see especially his attack on objectivist semantics)
-	Evans, Vyvyan and Melanie Green, Cognitive Linguistics: An Introduction, Routledge, 2006.
-	Montague, Richard (1970). English as a Formal Language. In B. Visentini (ed.), Linguaggi Nella Societ\'{a} e Nella Tecnica'. Edizioni di Communita. pp. 188-221.
-	Coppock, Elizabeth and Lucas Champollion, An Invitation to Formal Semantics [the preface and opening chapter: https://eecoppock.info/bootcamp/semantics-boot-camp.pdf] 
-	Thomas, Linda, Beginning Syntax, Wiley-Blackwell, 1993.

Speech Acts
-	Austin, JL, How to do things with Words, Harvard University Press, 1975.
-	Langton, Rae, Speech Acts and Unspeakable Acts, Philosophy & Public Affairs, 1993.

Experimental Philosophy of Language
-	Hansen, Nathaniel, 'Experimental Philosophy of Language', The Oxford Handbook of Topics in Philosophy, Oxford Academic, 2014.

description.et:
Overview

1.1. Two Views of Language--Generative Linguistics and Cognitive Linguistics 

Getting to Know the Target of Cognitive Linguists' Dissatisfaction

1.2 Generative Syntax--What does it look like? 
2.1 Compositional, truth-conditional semantics--What does it look like (1)?
2.2 Compositional, truth-conditional semantics--What does it look like (2)? 
3.1 Compositional, truth-conditional semantics--What does it look like(3)? + Workshop on the use of generative AI to engage in "discursive reading" of texts we use in this course
3.2 Graded Assignment: Formal Semantics--Revision and In-Class Challenge/Exam

4.1 Formal Semantics and a Gricean Semantics/Pragmatics Distinction

Objections

4.2 Cognitive Linguists' Objections: A Detailed Look
5.1 Reviewing Previous Weeks in Light of Cognitive Linguists' Objections

Getting to Know the Reality

5.2 Making semantic analyses more sophisticated: example--conditionals as modal restrictors
6.1 More than Just Putting Forth Content: Speech Acts
6.2 Graded Assignment: write draft at home, peer review in class: provide felicity-condition analysis of a novel speech act

7.1 Presuppositions (a variety of speech act felicity condition)
7.2 Presupposition as a Tool for Discrimination and Methods to Respond
8.1 Understanding Counterspeech in Light of Presuppositions
8.2 Assertions, Implicatures, Responsibility, and Plausible Deniability
9.1 Conceptual Analysis of Deniability

9.2 Graded Assignment: Development of scenes that manifest the different properties of implicatures, presuppositions, and entailments, and the problems of rejecting presuppositions. (no slurs allowed).
10.1 Graded Assignment: Film Screening -- scenes and their assessment.
10.2 Complicating the Gricean Semantics/Pragmatics Distinction: Context-Sensitivity (and a comparison with cognitive semantics)
11.1 Graded Assignment: constructing arguments for the existence of context-sensitivity in novel places.

11.2 What does Widespread Context-Sensitivity do to Compositional Truth-conditional Semantics?
12.1 Gradable Adjectives and Degrees in their Meaning
12.2 Gradable Adjectives and Formally Modelling Encoded Subjectivity
13.1 Graded Assignment: Revision and In-class Challenge/Exam on encoded subjectivity.

13.2 Too much context-sensitivity: how do we communicate? 
14.1 Do we need language regulation to communicate? The Estonian Language Institute and Semantic Deference to Experts
14.2 Debriefing: How do the cognitive linguists' objections fair?
Assignments due summarizing the extent that phil lang is based on data--based on diary entries on this topic from course.
15.1 Graded Assignment: Constructing social media dialogues between generative and cognitive linguists.
15.2 Graded Assignment: Screening of the dialogues
